Edsger W. Dijkstra

General

Edsger Dijkstra was born in Rotterdam, Netherlands in 1930. He specialized in mathematics, physics and programming allowing him to create groundbreaking theories. Dijkstra got his Turing Award in 1972 for inventing structured programming.
Structured programming revolutionized programming and made it accessible to the wider population. It used terms like if, then, else, while and for to make the program codes more ordered and easy to read by improving its quality.

Contributions

Edsger W. Dijkstra studied mathematics and physics at the University of Leiden. In 1952, Dijkstra became Netherlandâ€™s first programmer.
Dijkstra finished his PhD at the University of Amsterdam on the topic of 'Communication with an Automatic Computer' in which he explained the use of Assembly which was used on the first commercial computer, the Electrologica X1.
For ten years, starting in 1952 he worked Mathematisch Centrum alongside Bram Jan Loopstra and Carel S. Scholten in order to build a computer. Dijkstra was the one who would write the software for the machine. In 1960 he and his colleague Jaap Zonneveld developed the first compiler for ALGOL 60.
In 1962 Dijkstra became a professor at the Eindhoven University of Technology for the faculty of Mathematics and later built a team of programmers. With that group he created THE Operating System (THE OS) which was a computer operating system.
In 1971 Dijkstra became a member of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences and a Fellow of the British Computer Society. One year later he won the Turing Award.
In 1973 Dijkstra joined Burroughs Corporation and in his years of research there he wrote approximately 500 documents.
From 1984 till his retirement Dijkstra taught at the University of Texas in Austin. He retired in 1999 and returned to the Netherlands to die peacefully after a long battle with cancer. Dijkstra died in 2002.
Naming all the fields in which Dijkstra contributed is futile as they consist of most fields of software engineering.

In memory of A.M. Turing
